Message.Title: SPECTRUM THESIS - with additional note for Apple Investors
Message.Msg: --------------- (Posted here by request) --------------- Sometimes there is such a forceful overriding dynamic at work that nothing else much matters. In Sprint there appears to be such a situation. This is such a simple concept, it almosts hurts, it's TOO simple, we all tend to want a nice complex explanation as to why we should own a stock! Sprint/CLWR has the largest Spectrum holding of any company in the U.S...... and the FCC has already identified that we're going to run out of Spectrum as more and more wireless devices go online, in other words the Gov't is basically saying that Sprint's Spectrum will go to full capacity utilization.... .....essentially the Gov't just told us that Sprint's network is going to fill to the brim.....simply put, no matter what devices, whether it's smartphones or other consumer devives, smart grid or myriad M2M devices.....sprint's network is going to fill up...... with paying customers! (Note for Apple Investors) When I wrote this about 3 years ago I would not have conceived that this thesis might so significantly involve Apple and the iphone - such speaks to Apple's success that the Spectrum Thesis could almost be re-written to state that Sprint's Network is going to fill up with Apple iphones!

Message.Title: Samsung did not copy everything from the iPhone, and I can prove it
Message.Msg: The "tap" feature for the Samsung S III (you know, the big "new" differentiator) is a different name than the "bump" app that has long existed for the iPhone. So they didn't copy the name, they went out on a limb, innovating for weeks, trying to find something they could innovate and finally came up with a different name for the same functionality.. So Samsung has only copied 99.99999% of the iPhone, for those of you that thought it was a 100% copy.

Message.Title: Protect yourself: Apple stock and market already had prices in Huge expectations for iphone5 for too long, Anything come little short can be disaster
Message.Msg: can iPhone 5 Really Cut It Against Samsung Galaxy S3 that was not been a problem when iphone 4s release the Samsung Galaxy S3 is definitely one of the hottest phones of 2012, so does the iPhone 5 have any chance of beating it? Let’s take a look at the confirmed specs of the US Galaxy S3 and the specs we think are likely to belong to the iPhone 5. Rumors are usually better than the reality, but for the sake of argument, we’ll give them the benefit of the doubt here. Samsung Galaxy S3 vs iPhone 5 The Samsung Galaxy S3 has a lovely 4.8” screen – Super AMOLED with 310ppi and 1280×720. It’s thought that the iPhone 5 will sport a bigger screen than its predecessors – probably around 4”, with most likely a 1280x720p, 367ppi resolution. It’s debatable as to whether the human eye needs a higher resolution than 310, and it’s also debatable that people want a 4.8” or bigger screen. It’s thought that the iPhone 5 will have the A5X processor, compared to the dual-core Snapdragon in the S3. Both chips will be superb, and only benchmark tests will be able to choose a winner. However, the flexibility each chip gives to the OS will be the real world test. When the Samsung Galaxy S3 came out it had the latest Android OS, and the iPhone 5 is bound to sport iOS 6. JellyBean has been announced recently, so the S3 is, for the moment, behind the times, but an update is expected soon. The Samsung Galaxy S3 isn’t in the Nexus series, so if you’re into updates, go for the iPhone 5. The Samsung Galaxy S3 camera is 8MP and has a burst mode and no shutter lag. The new iPhone 5 is expected to have an 8MP camera as well, so this may end up as a tie. In terms of storage the Samsung Galaxy S3 comes in 16GB, 32GB and 64GB versions, with SD Card support. The iPhone 5 may well lack the external storage options just like everyone of its predecessors. The Samsung Galaxy S3 software tweaks include S-Beam, S-Voice, Pop Up Play and Smart Stay, and the iPhone 5 will probably have Siri 2.0, Universal Remote Control, Face Unlock and a host of unknowns. Apple fans will insist that the iPhone 5 will trounce the Samsung Galaxy S3, but Android fans will not be parted from their S3s. With the Samsung Galaxy S3 being so popular right now, Apple will have to come up with something more than just another in-line upgrade which the 4S was seen over the iPhone 4.

Topic.Title: If apple making Samsung mad they may delay few parts for iphone 5 'till after Christmas, they can sell more GIII, and Appl stock can down to $400 easy

Message.Msg: Apple has been known to make huge prepayment for parts in order to guarantee supply. It doesn't take a genius to realize that the guarantee would involve specific performance metrics that come with severe penalties if missed. If a shortage arises, Apple gets its supply first and the small fries suffer. Sammy can't breach this contract. Regardless, the OP does not understand business logic. The first rule of a business is to protect and grow your revenue. The OP acts as if the first rule is to spite your competitors. Sue, when your revenue streams are good, and you have satisfied the business rules, then you can engage in spite as a bonus. But you certainly don't purposely give up your parts revenue from Apple (which is plentiful) just to spite your biggest customer. Thompson

Topic.Title: If apple making Samsung mad they may delay few parts for iphone 5 'till after Christmas, they can sell more GIII, and Appl stock can down to $400 easy

Message.Msg: If these are FRAND patents, which every vendors is FORCED to use (unlike other patents, which vendors are compelled to not use without permission) then Motorola is supposed to offer fair licenses. This is the cost of going FRAND. You get guaranteed high volume for users of your patents coupled with low per unit license revenue. Both Sammy and Motorola have been trying to unfairly soak Apple more than other vendors. Probably because that seems to be the only recourse to slow the Cuprtino giant. Thompson

Topic.Title: Samung the F700 was actually first announced in February 2007 — a month after Steve Jobs debuted the iPhone — and was released in December 2007, months after the iPhone’s debut. Worse, it was greeted with accusations of being a complete iPhone ripoff! Not to mention whole world knows iPhone was blatant copycat from a award wining LG prada phone that debuted in 2006

Message.Msg: iPhone was very different from LG Prada. The only similarity was that they were both rectangular touchscreens (kind of like the etch-a-sketch!) and the differences in use were tremendous. The iPhone was so revolutionary in its new capabilities that the LG Prada was relegated to the dust bin of history, along with tons of other phones too. Isn't it amazing that the only phone maker other than Apple that is doing well right now is Samsung, and they are the only ones that deliberately cloned the iPhone right down to the gnat's patootie. People that use this LG Prada argument make me laugh. It's almost as if they STILL don't understand what the impact of the iPhone was... 5 years later. I guess some people just never figure it out, even when it is right under their noses. Thompson

Message.Title: Blue Horseshoe likes Oct deep in the money calls
Message.Msg: The Oct 500s or so give you all the upside for the iPhone announcement and feeding frenzy with very little premium because they expire prior to the earnings announcement. For example, as of the close Friday you could pick up the Oct 500s for an ask of $122.25 (anything above $622.25 is pure profit) on a closing price of $621.70 ... you give up 55 cents of upside profit ... no brainer if you believe the iPhone 5 is coming out in September and it will drive the share price higher. Now just imagine a mini iPad or stock split in the same timeframe.

Topic.Title: Blue Horseshoe likes Oct deep in the money calls

Message.Msg: Sorry, 124.65 ... so a few bucks of upside for a very small investment vs buying the shares.

Topic.Title: MITT ROMNEY & PAUL RYAN--REAL AMERICANS TO TAKE BACK OUR COUNTRY...

Message.Msg: blkvette87 -- Very well said. Let us hope that the majority of voters see the light - and realize that Owebama is the worst thing to happen to American since Carter. Owebama = Entitlement Society - Dependent on Government handouts; Success and hard work is PUNISHED with high taxes; Government limits YOUR FREEDOM with intrusive regulations throughout society, disjointing the financial markets, etc. etc. Romney = Capitalism - Self-reliance and incentives for "Capital-Creation" such as a low tax burden, few government regulations, USA Energy Independence (using OUR resources, not importing/sending OUR money overseas), etc. The choice is clear. If you hate America and want to see America changed into a European-style Socialist Society, then vote Owebama. If you appreciate the fact that FREEDOM unleashed in America has changed the world for the better through innovation, investment and job creation, then vote Romney. Ronald Reagan gave America hope again after the miserable Carter years. I truly believe that Romney's business experience may SAVE AMERICA from the miserable, stalled-growth economic recovery we are now experiencing. If you use your brain in the voting booth in November, then the choice is clear. American did not become an economic superpower on the back of a big, bloated debt-spending Federal Government. America became great because of Entrepreneurs like Steve Jobs & Woz forming a business in a garage....taking a risk to do something great!

Message.Title: We have China folks....
Message.Msg: Apple is Feeling the LOVE in China By Aabha Rathee | More Articles August 12, 2012 The iPad has had its fair share of controversies in China, but the Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) device is clearly unaffected by any bad publicity and is in a position of unrivaled domination in the country’s tablet market. According to a new survey from market research firm Analysys International, the iPad contributed to 72.6 percent of total tablet shipments in China. Don’t Miss: Is This New Apple Technology a GIANT THREAT to Google? To top that, none of Apple’s rivals even cracked a 10 percent share. Second-ranked Lenovo held a market share of 8.38 percent, while Samsung, in fourth place behind Eben, had barely 3.59 percent. Google’s (NASDAQ:GOOG) Motorola Mobility came in at a dismal tenth place with an embarrassing 0.26 percent share. Chinese consumers purchased a total of 2.34 million tablets during the second quarter of the year, a 63 percent year-over-year increase.
